title: Frederic Newton
text:
Frederic Young Newton (April 7, 1870–May 17, 1959) was a politician in <a href="Manitoba">Manitoba</a>, Canada. He served in the <a href="Legislative%20Assembly%20of%20Manitoba">Legislative Assembly of Manitoba</a> from 1911 to 1917, and again from 1922 to 1932. He was a member of the <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Manitoba">Conservative Party</a>.
Newton was born in <a href="Cobourg%2C%20Ontario">Cobourg</a>, <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>, the son of John White Newton and Mary McCullough, and was educated at <a href="Winnipeg%2C%20Manitoba">Winnipeg</a> Collegiate. In 1910, he served as <a href="Reeve%20%28Canada%29">reeve</a> of the <a href="Rural%20Municipality%20of%20Shell%20River">Rural Municipality of Shell River</a>. In 1904, Newton married C.I. Gilchrist. He was mayor of the village of <a href="Roblin%2C%20Manitoba">Roblin</a> from 1920 to 1922 and from 1940 to 1943. He worked as a broker and was president of the Roblin Loan & Investment Co.
He was first elected to the Manitoba legislature in a <a href="by-election">by-election</a> held on February 4, 1911 in the constituency of <a href="Russell%20%28Manitoba%20riding%29">Russell</a>, defeating <a href="Manitoba%20Liberal%20Party">Liberal</a> William Valens by 265 votes. He was re-elected by 231 votes in the <a href="1914%20Manitoba%20general%20election">1914 provincial election</a>, in the constituency of <a href="Roblin%20%28Manitoba%20riding%29">Roblin</a>. During this period, Newton served as a backbench supporter of <a href="Rodmond%20Roblin">Rodmond Roblin</a>'s government.
The Roblin government was forced to resign amid scandal in 1915, and the Conservatives were badly defeated in <a href="1915%20Manitoba%20general%20election">that year's provincial election</a>. Newton was one of only five Conservatives to retain his seat, and was the only Conservative elected in an anglophone riding. He resigned his seat in 1917, after a report of the province's Paterson Commission found evidence of road frauds in his constituency.
Newton sought a return to the legislature in the <a href="1920%20Manitoba%20general%20election">1920 provincial election</a>, but lost to Farmer candidate <a href="Henry%20Robson%20Richardson">Henry Robson Richardson</a> by 104 votes. He tried again in the <a href="1922%20Manitoba%20general%20election">1922 election</a>, and this time defeated Richardson by nine votes. The election was won by the <a href="United%20Farmers%20of%20Manitoba">United Farmers of Manitoba</a>, and Newton served on the opposition benches.
He was re-elected in the <a href="1927%20Manitoba%20general%20election">1927 election</a>, and again served as an opposition member. In the <a href="1932%20Manitoba%20general%20election">1932 election</a>, he lost to independent <a href="Progressive%20Party%20of%20Manitoba">Progressive</a> <a href="William%20Westwood%20%28Manitoba%20politician%29">William Westwood</a> by 609 votes.
Newton died in Roblin at the age of 89.
